name: Hyssop (Ezov)
uses: Passover - applied lamb's blood to doorposts with hyssop bunch
Red Heifer purification - essential in creating purification waters
Tzaraat cleansing - ritual purification from spiritual impurity
Temple incense (Ketoret) - component of sacred incense blend
Psalm 51:7 - 'Purge me with hyssop and I shall be clean'
sacredSignificance: Biblical purification plant. Used in most important Jewish purification rituals. Symbolizes humility (grows from walls). Essential to Temple service. Represents divine cleansing and forgiveness.
preparationMethods: Biblical bundle: tied together, dipped in blood or purification water
Hyssop tea: 1-2 tsp dried leaves per cup, steep 10 minutes
Za'atar blend: primary ingredient in Middle Eastern spice mix
Not used ritually since Temple destruction (70 CE)
safetyWarnings: essential oil toxic - do not ingest

jewish.usage: Temple purification, red heifer ritual, Passover blood application, tzaraat cleansing
jewish.significance: Symbol of humility and divine purification. Contrasted with cedar (pride) in rituals.

christian.usage: Vinegar offered to Jesus on hyssop branch at crucifixion
christian.significance: Connects to Passover lamb imagery, baptismal purification symbolism

kabbalistic.significance: Associated with Chesed (loving-kindness) and divine mercy washing away sin

description: Hyssop (Ezov) is a figure from ancient mythology.
subtitle: Hyssop (Ezov) is a figure from ancient mythology.
